facts.text: Appeal from High Court of Bombay judgment dated 9th March 1943 in Second Appeal No. 717 of 1940.

anchor.surface_text: APPEAL from the High Court of Judicature at Bombay Appeal No. XXXVII of 1949. This was an appeal from a judgment and decree of the Bombay High Court dated 9th March, 1943, in Second Appeal No. 717 of 1940, varying the decree of the Assistant Judge, Ahmeda- bad, in Appeal No. 173 of 1936 reversing the decree of the joint Sub-Judge, Ahmedabad, in Suit No. 830 of 1933.

facts.text: Suit No. 830 of 1933 filed by respondent firm in July 1933 for ejectment of survey Nos. 222, 223, 225 and 226 in Rampura, Ahmedabad district, and mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: The suit out of which this appeal arises was filed by the respondent firm in ejectment to recover possession of survey Nos. 222, 223, 225 and 226 situate in Rampura in Ahmedabad district and for mesne profits, as early as July, 1933, and during its 17 years span of life it had a some- what chequered career.

facts.text: Bhankoda talukdari estate in Viramgam taluka, Ahmedabad district, jointly owned by several talukdars, comprises twelve villages including Rampura.

anchor.surface_text: There is a talukdari estate called the Bhankoda estate in Viramgam taluka in Ahmedabad district. It is jointly owned by several talukdars in different shares and companyprises twelve villages one of which is Rampura in which the suit lands are situate.

facts.text: Government Resolution No. 8170 dated 30th August 1912 took Bhankoda estate under Government management under section 28 of Gujarat Talukdars Act (Bombay Act VI of 1888).

anchor.surface_text: By Government Resolution No. 8170, dated 30th August 1912, the estate was taken under Government management under section 28 of the Gujarat Talukdars Act  Bombay Act VI of 1888 . The firm of Shah Manilal Maganlal and Bros.  predecessors in interest of the appellant  de- sired to erect a ginning factory on survey Nos. 228, 225, and 226 and with that object approached the Talukdari Set- tlement Officer for a permanent lease of these survey num- bers.

facts.text: Shah Manilal Maganlal and Bros., predecessors of appellant, desired permanent lease of survey Nos. 228, 225, 226 for ginning factory.

anchor.surface_text: The firm of Shah Manilal Maganlal and Bros.  predecessors in interest of the appellant  de- sired to erect a ginning factory on survey Nos. 228, 225, and 226 and with that object approached the Talukdari Set- tlement Officer for a permanent lease of these survey num- bers. The said officer agreed to grant a lease subject to sanction of Government.

facts.text: Government Resolution No. 10795 dated 5th September 1917 sanctioned the lease.

anchor.surface_text: By Resolution No. 10795 of 1917 dated 5th September 1917 the Government of Bombay granted the requisite sanction. Exhibit 181 is a certified companyy of the letter from the Chief Secretary to Government to the Commissioner and to the Talukdari Settlement Officer and in detail it mentions the various steps taken to effect the transaction.

facts.text: On 9th December 1916, Shah Manilal Maganlal applied in writing for permanent lease of survey numbers at Rs. 290 annual rental.

anchor.surface_text: On 9th December 1916 an application was made by Shah Manilal Maganlal in writing signed by him to the Talukdari Settlement Officer offering to take a permanent lease of the above mentioned survey numbers on an annual rental of Rs. 290 for the purpose of erecting a ginning factory.

facts.text: On 12th July 1917, Talukdari Settlement Officer provisionally accepted the offer.

anchor.surface_text: On 12th July 1917 the said officer accepted provisionally this offer after taking into companysideration the objections raised by some of the talukdars in respect of the grant of a lease.

facts.text: Binding agreement to lease effected between Talukdari Settlement Officer and Shah Manilal Maganlal with Government sanction.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that a binding agreement to lease the survey numbers in question was effected between the Talukdari Settlement Officer and Shah Manilal Maganlal with the sanc- tion of the Government.

facts.text: Lessee took possession soon after agreement, erected ginning and pressing factory, bungalow, etc.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after the agreement the lessee took possession of the survey numbers in suit and put up thereupon a ginning and a pressing factory, a bungalow, engine rooms and other structures.

facts.text: Lessee tendered and paid agreed rent to Talukdari Settlement Officer for about two years.

anchor.surface_text: He tendered the agreed rent to the Talukdari Settlement Officer who received it from him. He companytinued receiving it for about two years when the estate was re- leased from the management of the Government and came under the management of the talukdars.

facts.text: On 4th May 1924, Shah Manilal Maganlal executed possessory mortgage of ginning factory for Rs. 1,40,000 in favour of defendant.

anchor.surface_text: On 4th May, 1924, a possessory mortgage of the ginning factory along with all its buildings was effected by Shah Manilal Maganlal in the sum of Rs. 1,40,000 in favour of the defendant.

facts.text: Appellant purchased equity of redemption of suit property at court auction in 1933.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1933 the appellant purchased the equity of redemption of the suit property at a companyrt auction and became vested with all the rights of Mani- lal Maganlal in this property, the value of which has number been estimated in the neighbourhood of Rs. 38,000.

facts.text: Plaintiffs received rent according to the grant up to 31st July 1932.

anchor.surface_text: In the 8th paragraph it was said that the plaintiffs received the amount of the lease up to 31st July 1932 and that numbernotice was necessary to be given, the position of the defendant being that of a trespasser.

facts.text: Plaint admits correspondence negotiating 50-year lease at Rs. 290 but claims no formal registered lease, so trespassers.

anchor.surface_text: In the 2nd and 3rd paragraphs of the plaint it was admitted that in .the companyrse of the companyrespondence with the Government of Bombay a lease was negotiated between the firm of Shah Manilal Maganlal and the Talukari Settlement Officer in respect of the survey numbers in dispute for a period of fifty years at an annual rental of Rs. 290, but it was stated that because Manilal Maganlal did number execute a formal registered lease they were in possession as trespassers.

facts.text: Trial Judge (Joint Sub-Judge, Ahmedabad) decreed suit for plaintiffs, finding no written lease.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge decreed the suit on the finding that as numberwritten lease was forthcoming it should be deemed to be number-existent.

facts.text: Assistant Judge, Ahmedabad, Appeal No. 173 of 1936, on 27th April 1940 allowed defendant's appeal applying section 53-A TP Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Judge allowed the appeal on 27th April, 1940. He held that the plaintiffs had failed to establish their right to maintain the suit either as ijaradars or as assign- ees of mortgage rights.

facts.text: High Court of Bombay, Second Appeal No. 717 of 1940, dated 9th March 1943, allowed plaintiffs' appeal partially, decreed for 223,225, dismissed for 222,226.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the appeal and modified the decree of the Assistant Judge. It decreed the plaintiffs suit in respect of survey Nos. 223 and 225 and dismissed the suit in respect of survey Nos. 222 and 226,

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal judgment delivered by MAHAJAN J. on March 21, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. March 21. The judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by MAHAJAN J .--This is an appeal from the judgment and decree of the High Court of Bombay dated 9th March 1943 and made in Second Appeal No. 717 of 1940 varying the decree of the Assistant Judge, Ahmedabad, in Appeal No. 173 of 1936 reversing the decree of the Joint Sub-Judge, Ahmedabad, in Suit No. 830 of 1933.

facts.text: Supreme Court held defendant entitled to protection under section 53-A Transfer of Property Act based on written agreement evidenced by Ex. 181.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the defendant has fulfilled both the companydi- tions necessary to attract the application of the section in the present case.

facts.text: No formal lease deed executed or registered.

anchor.surface_text: Though a draft of a formal deed of lease was prepared, numbersuch document was formally executed or registered for reasons which it is number necessary to state herein.

facts.text: Plaintiffs as ijaradar and assignee of mortgage rights, receiving rent.

anchor.surface_text: The two companytestants in the suit, the defendant and the plaintiffs, acquired their rights in this property during the years 1924-25. The defend ant came in as a mortgagee as above stated, while the plaintiffs came in as ijaradar and assign- ees of certain mortgage rights.

facts.text: On remand, trial judge admitted Ex. 181 and other documents.

anchor.surface_text: He also admitted in evidence a number of documents produced after remand and one of these is Ex. 181.

facts.text: Defendant paid rent to plaintiffs for survey Nos. 223, 225, 226 for all 100 Dakdas.

anchor.surface_text: on the defendants own admission he has paid rent to the plaintiff for three of the suit fields, viz., survey Nos. 223, 225, and 226, and that too number the interest of 84 Dakdas in them but for all the 100 Dakdas.

anchor.surface_text: we consider that the Assistant Judge was right in entertaining and giving effect to the plea under sec. 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act and we are satisfied that no substantial grounds existed for reversing- that deci- sion in second appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defendant's predecessor entered into written signed agreement to lease evidenced by Ex.181; took possession, built structures, paid rent in part performance; willing to perform remainder; bars ejectment.

holdings.text: Ex. 181 constitutes evidence of a written contract signed by the transferor from which terms necessary to constitute the transfer can be ascertained with reasonable certainty.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was in error when it held that the correspondence summarised in Ex. 181 could not be treated as evidence of the contract and that its terms could not be reasonably deduced from this document.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ex.181 is government resolution detailing signed offer, provisional acceptance, sanction; recites terms (permanent lease, Rs.290 rent, revisable after 50 years); reliable secondary evidence as originals withheld.

holdings.text: Ex. 181 is good secondary evidence of the agreement of lease.

anchor.surface_text: It is not doubt true that Ex. 181 is merely secondary evidence of the agreement of lease but it is equally true that it is a very reliable piece of secondary evidence coming as it does from government records.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Primary documents in possession/power of plaintiff/talukdars, not produced despite notice; Ex.181 official record proves contents; plaintiff admits knowledge via plaint.

holdings.text: A binding agreement to lease was effected between the Talukdari Settlement Officer and Shah Manilal Maganlal with the sanction of the Government.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that a binding agreement to lease the survey numbers in question was effected between the Talukdari Settlement Officer and Shah Manilal Maganlal with the sanc- tion of the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sequence of signed written offer (9/12/1916), provisional acceptance (12/7/1917), government sanction (5/9/1917) via Ex.181.

holdings.text: The learned Assistant Judge rightly dismissed the plaintiffs suit and the High Court was in error in interfering with that decision in second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the learned Assist- ant Judge rightly dismissed the plaintiffs suit and the High Court was in error in interfering with that decision in second appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All conditions of s.53A satisfied; High Court wrongly rejected Ex.181 as proof of contract.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to consider and decide whether the plaintiff firm has proved its title to maintain the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.53A plea sufficient to bar suit regardless of title, as debarment applies to transferor or claimants under him.

holdings.text: An agreement of lease creating a present demise but not registered is admissible under S. 49 of the Indian Registration Act as evidence of part performance.

anchor.surface_text: admissible under S. 49 of the Indian Registra- tion Act as evidence of part performance and Ex. 181 is secondary evidence of that agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.49 allows unregistered documents for collateral purposes like proving part performance under s.53A.

holdings.text: A formal lease is not necessary to attract the application of S. 53-A; an agreement in writing signed by the transferor sufficient if gathered from evidence.

anchor.surface_text: A formal lease is not necessary to attract the application of S. 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act. All that is required is that an agreement in writing signed by the transferor can be gath- ered from the evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.53A requires only writing signed by transferor with ascertainable terms, not registered formal deed.
